section-block.rac_essential-question: What do we do better together?

section-block.rac_book_caption: Big Book: The One Day House

section-block.rac_book_title_byline: Written by Julia Durango and illustrated by Bianca Diaz
section-block.rac_book_summary: Wilson has big plans to fix up Gigi’s house! Let’s read to see how everyone works together to help Gigi!

section-block.rac_top-left_header: READY, SET, GO | WEEK 1: We Can Do It

section-block.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Use the Ee, Kk, Ll Alphabet Cards.
section-block.rac_body-text: Tell children that today we will review the letters Ee, Kk, and Ll.
Invite children to act out how they would do each task as you sing “Building Up Gigi’s House”. Encourage them to take initiative by designing their own movements.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read a narrative called The One Day House by Julia Durango.
Pablo loves narratives about people and their neighbors! This narrative is about Wilson helping Gigi fix her house.
I have a question I want you to keep in mind while we read. When we’re done reading, we will try to answer it together. Ready?
What are some things Wilson plans on doing one day?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 1 prompts.
Use Equity Sticks to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Wilson wants to paint Gigi’s house like the sun. What do you see on these pages?
I see the letter e in the word breeze. What sound does the letter e make in the word breeze?
I see the letter k in the word keep. What sound does the letter k make in the word keep?
I see the letter E in the word Everyone. What sound does the letter E make in the word Everyone?
I see the letter l in the word like. What sound does the letter l make in the word like?
Why does Wilson want Gigi’s house to be snug?
Wilson tells his class he wants to plant Gigi a garden. What do you see on these pages?
Let’s turn and talk about the guiding question:
What are some things Wilson plans on doing one day?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, choose two or three children to share their responses.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: He wants to fix Gigi’s windows.
He wants to fix Gigi’s chimney.
He wants to plant Gigi a garden.

section.rac_body-text: Write and read aloud short sentences giving your opinion about Wilson’s action.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Does Wilson want to paint Gigi’s house?
Wilson wants to p______ (paint) Gigi’s house.
Wilson wants to paint Gigi’s house.
Why does Wilson want to fix Gigi’s house?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Allow multilingual children to share translations for words like paint, fence, stairs, roof, and piano. Allowing children to teach others about their culture can help them feel a sense of pride in their cultural identity, It also helps to instill confidence in language skills for both English-speaking children and non-native speakers.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: READY, SET, GO | WEEK 1: We Can Do It

section-block.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule_day_2: Share the Mind Builder: Take Initiative
section-block.rac_body-text: Explain to children that Wilson sees many problems at Gigi’s house, and decides he will solve them. He takes the first steps. Tell children that when we show initiative and persist to solve a problem, it can make us feel proud. Ask children to describe how they would feel if they were able to solve a problem like Wilson did.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread The One Day House by Julia Durango. This time, we’ll notice how Wilson sees a problem and works hard until he solves it.
Clifford tries to take initiative and solve problems, but sometimes has to ask Emily Elizabeth for help! He wonders if Wilson from the story asks for help sometimes, too.

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to the Mind Builder
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Let’s reread The One Day House and talk about some pages that show us how Wilson takes initiative to solve problems.
section.rac_body-text: Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Look at Wilson’s drawing. What problem does Wilson want to solve? Why did Wilson count boards and nails? (MB)
What problem does Wilson want to solve on this page? Why did he draw a picture of rope, a brush, and a heavy ball? (MB)
What problem does Wilson want to solve? Why does Wilson want to fix Gigi’s piano? (MB)
Wilson asked for help! How do you think all of the people will solve problems in Gigi’s house? (MB)
How do you think everyone feels as they work together? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Make a simple pattern with pattern blocks. Have children work together in groups to match the pattern with their own pattern blocks. Tell children to ask each other for help if needed. If they ask for help, try to get them to clearly state the problem; then, have children work together to find a solution. Compliment their persistence and initiative in asking for help. (MB)

Transcribe children’s speech as they talk about how Wilson solved each of Gigi’s problems. Have children draw a picture that shows how Wilson felt after all the problems in Gigi’s house were solved. (MB)

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Learning to take initiative is a critical skill for young children to learn. It increases their willingness to try new ideas on their own and to have self-confidence. Encourage children to explore their own interests and allow children to find creative solutions to problems. (Epstein, A. (2007). The Intentional Teacher.)

section-block.rac_top-left_header: READY, SET, GO | WEEK 1: We Can Do It

section-block.rac_body-text: Explain that we can use clues in The One Day House and background knowledge to make a smart guess.
Sing the “Family Helper” song. Model filling in the blank with a chore, before allowing each child to take a turn filling it in.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we are going to reread the narrative The One Day House by Julia Durango.
Pablo loves reading narratives about how a community can help each other!
Keep in mind this question as we reread today:
Why does Wilson want to help Gigi?

section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the book and the Day 3 prompts. Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to answer questions.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What do you know about the sun? How does being in sunshine make you feel? Make an inference about why you think Gigi calls Wilson her “sunshine.”
What do you know about chimneys? Make an inference about how a fire would keep Gigi cozy.
Why are all the people at Gigi’s house? What are they going to do?
How are the people in the community fixing Gigi’s house? Describe what you see in the pictures.
How do you think Gigi feels about her house? How do you think Gigi feels about her community? Use clues from the pictures and the text to help you make an inference.
Think about our guiding question while we reread our book:
Why does Wilson want to help Gigi?
section.rac_body-text: Give a moment for Turn and Talk. Then, choose two or three children to share their answers.
Possible answers:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: Wilson wants Gigi to be happy.
Wilson wants to help take care of Gigi.

section.rac_body-text: Discuss the inferences children found in the story and work with children to write about them using words, letters, or drawings. Have children share and discuss the results.

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Does Wilson want Gigi to be happy?
Wilson wants Gigi to be h________ (happy).
Wilson wants Gigi to be happy.
How do you think Wilson got his community involved?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Making inferences by using graphics is a useful skill for children, especially later when reading informational textbooks. Introduce children to the concept of making inferences by “reading between the lines”—using text clues. This skill allows readers to gain a deeper understanding of a narrative.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: READY, SET, GO | WEEK 1: We Can Do It

section-block.rac_body-text: Explain to children that working together can make a job go faster. Sharing ideas and materials can make a project turn out better.
Sing the song “The More We Get Together” with children, pointing to each child as you use their name. Then talk about how things can be more fun with more friends!

section.rac_column_heds_no_paragraph_rule: Share the Big Chart of Big Ideas
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: This week we are going to read a narrative from the poster called We Have Soup! It tells about a community coming together.
Pablo loves soup! He is excited to find out how the rabbits work together in the story to make a yummy soup!
In both The One Day House and We Have Soup!, friends and neighbors help each other and work together. Let’s try to find some examples to see how these stories are alike.
As we read the Big Chart, let’s talk about the concept question for the week:
What can we do better together?

section.rac_column_heds_with_rule: Close-Read: Connect to We Can Do It
section.rac_body-text: Read aloud the teacher text on the Big Chart, then use these prompts to read and discuss the pictures on the poster.
Use Equity Sticks during reading to choose children to answer.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: What problem are the rabbits trying to solve? What do they need for their soup?
What problem is Wilson trying to solve? Why can’t Wilson fix Gigi’s house himself?
What do Carlos and Clara Rabbit add to the soup? Why do they add it?
How do all of the rabbits work together to make the soup better? What did they learn?
What do all of Wilson’s neighbors add to make the house better?

section.rac_body-text: Have children pretend they are rabbits from Claudia’s village. Place a container on the table and let them all add a pretend food to the soup. They can use objects or pictures they draw. Discuss the resulting soup and how their group effort made it better.
Provide a writing prompt about working in groups to do something or make something that they couldn’t do by themselves.

section-block.rac_child_development_body: You’re in a position to lay the foundation for a skill that will be essential throughout children’s lives. Encourage teamwork through activities, games, and projects that require teamwork. Provide feedback on their efforts of working together. Teamwork nurtures skills needed for interpersonal thinking and encourages feelings of community connection.

section-block.rac_top-left_header: READY, SET, GO | WEEK 1: We Can Do It

section-block.rac_body-text: Invite children to show and tell which project they would have wanted to work on if they had been involved in helping Wilson fix up Gigi’s house. If you see children using tools, elicit the name of the tool (for example, banging a hammer). Teach them the word if they don’t know it. Follow up by asking them to use the word while telling what they are doing.

section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Today we’re going to reread the story, The One Day House by Julia Durango, and talk about how the story is like things from our life. We will also talk about some of the illustrations by Bianca Diaz.
Pablo loves narratives about people helping others!
You’ve had time to think about this book, and we’re going to share some of your thoughts today. As we reread, keep in mind your answers to this question:
How are you like Wilson?

section.rac_body-text: Reread and retell the big book together. Use Equity Sticks to choose children to actively participate in the prompts below.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Wilson wants to do something nice for Gigi because he loves her. Who do you like to do nice things for?
Wilson tells Gigi he will build a fence so she can have a dog “to keep you company.”
section.rac_hilight_teacher_inst_new: Revisit keep you company Vocab Card.
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Why might a dog keep Gigi company?
WIlson wants to fix Gigi’s piano. Let’s pretend to play Gigi’s piano!
Wilson helped to get all these people to come to Gigi’s house! He knew he couldn’t do this big job alone. How do you know when it is time to ask grown-ups for help?
Let’s pretend that we came over to help Gigi’s house! What will you fix?
Wilson has made Gigi very happy. Do you see Wilson’s smile? He feels good about helping. He is proud of himself. What are you proud about? (MB)

section.rac_body-text: Give children a moment to Turn and Talk and answer the guiding question:
section.rac_teacher-talk_blue: How are you like Wilson?
section.rac_body-text: Then, using Equity Sticks, choose two or three children to share.
Possible responses:
section.rac_body-text_bulleted: I work hard to get things done.
I like to do nice things for my family.

section.rac_body-text: Invite children to draw or write about one way they help at home, school, or in their community and how they feel about it. What does proud feel like and look like?

rac_support_challenge-box.rac_teacher-talk_blue: Do you like to do nice things for your family?
I like to do nice things for my f________ (family).
I like to do nice things for my family.
What nice things have you done for your family?

section-block.rac_child_development_body: Self-awareness is difficult for young children. It’s not just about recognizing feelings; self-awareness empowers children to know that how they react to those feelings affects others—for better or worse. Being self-aware makes it easier for children to empathize with others, and recognize their strengths and weakness.
